statement.tex: \text{Write the integrating factor of the following} \\ \text{differential equation} \\ \left(1+y^2\right)dx - \left(tan^{-1}y-x\right)dy=0

step.context: \text{To find the integrating factor for a differential } \\ \text{equation, is the following form appropriate}
step.tex: \dfrac{dx}{dy}+xP=Q \\ \text{where P and Q are constants or functions of y}
\dfrac{dy}{dx}+xP=Q \\ \text{where P and Q are constants or functions of y}
step.reason: \dfrac{dx}{dy}+xP=Q \text{ is correct. Here's why.} \\ \text{Multiply both sides by }e^{\int P\, dy} \\ \begin{align} &e^{\int P\, dy}\dfrac{dx}{dy}+xPe^{\int P\, dy}=Qe^{\int P\, dy} \\ \implies & \dfrac{d}{dy}\left(x\cdot e^{\int P\, dy}\right) = Qe^{\int P\, dy} \\ \implies & x\cdot e^{\int P\, dy} = \int Qe^{\int P\, dy} \, dy+C \end{align} \\ \text{Since P and Q are either constants or functions} \\ \text{of y, we've arrived at a general solution.}
